LncRNAs are a class of non-coding RNAs that are longer than 200 nucleotides and have been found to be involved in various biological processes, including gene regulation.
One of the ways lncRNAs influence mRNA translation is by interacting with the 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs) of mRNA molecules. The 5' UTR contains elements that can bind to microRNAs (miRNAs), which are small RNA molecules that can inhibit or enhance mRNA translation. LncRNAs can compete with miRNAs for binding to the 5' UTR, thereby preventing miRNA-mediated repression of mRNA translation.
Additionally, lncRNAs can also interact with the 3' UTR, which contains polyadenylation sites that determine the cleavage and polyadenylation (CPA) site of the mRNA molecule. The CPA site affects mRNA stability and translation, and lncRNAs can modulate the CPA site by binding to it and altering the stability of the mRNA molecule.
Furthermore, lncRNAs can also influence mRNA translation by interacting with other trans-acting factors, such as RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) and chromatin-associated proteins. These interactions can affect the localization and stability of mRNA molecules, thereby influencing their translation.
Overall, the statement "Trans-acting factors, such as lncRNAs, influence mRNA translation" is fact-based and supported by evidence from various studies. LncRNAs, in particular, have been shown to play a crucial role in regulating gene expression by influencing mRNA translation through various mechanisms.
